timeline.summary: Emails between individuals at the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAFLS) regarding Jeffrey Epstein’s plea deal. One individual expressed gratitude to another for facilitating the plea, stating it was a significant achievement and that Epstein would have otherwise escaped justice. Another individual expressed shock at the outcome. A PDF file named "News Briefings 07 01 08.pdf" is referenced.

A communication regarding detailed briefing memos was sent on February 19, 2019, from the Chief Public Corruption Unit of the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York to Geoffrey Berman and others. The memo requested teams provide the briefings by Thursday morning, covering information related to Epstein.

A meeting is scheduled with the Attorney General (AG) on Monday regarding sensitive cases, including political and Epstein-related matters. Preparations involve providing detailed briefing memos to the brass by Thursday morning, derived from drafts to be delivered tomorrow. The individual is unavailable on Friday.

Geoffrey Berman (USANYS) sent an email on February 19, 2019, to [REDACTED] requesting detailed briefing memos regarding Epstein, to be delivered by Thursday morning from the Chief Public Corruption Unit of the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. The email included a reference to file EFTA00027926.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email requesting a brief meeting (5-10 minutes) regarding an update on Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email proposed a meeting time of 11:30 AM, and a subsequent email confirmed the meeting request. The emails were sent to multiple recipients with redacted names.

An individual ([REDACTED]) requests a 302 form related to a case involving “v4TVPA and Forfeiture.docx” and victims’ debriefings. They state they haven’t found any 302s or interview notes on the shared files and need the form to complete a discussion section. The email was sent from USANYS on May 20, 2019.

An email chain discusses the distribution of two memos – one from Geoff and one from the sender – related to DAG briefings with Ed. The memos address recusal matters, with the addition of Epstein after a conversation between the sender and Geoff. Only the non-recused memo is to be passed to Geoff. The email originates from [REDACTED] (USANYS) and includes attachments: SDNY_Memo_to_DAG.GSB.cases.5.23.19.final.pdf and SDNY_Memo_to_DAG_- _GSB_Recused.5.23.19.Finaldocx.pdf.

An email exchange occurred between individuals associated with USANYS and ODAG regarding two memos related to recusal matters. One memo was from Geoff and one from the sender, concerning Ed of the DAG. Following a conversation, Epstein was added to the briefing materials. The memos themselves (SDNY Memo to DAG.GSB.cases.5.23.19.final.pdf and SDNY Memo to DAG - GSB Recused.5.23.19.Finaldocx.pdf) were shared.

U.S. District Judge Loretta A. Preska allowed Alan Dershowitz’s motion to disqualify Boies Schiller Flexner LLP from representing the accuser in a sexual assault case. The motion stemmed from a conflict of interest regarding Dershowitz’s prior relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and the accuser, stemming from a 2015 offer of representation by Boies Schiller partner Carlos Sires. Dershowitz argued the conflict was “severe” and that Boies Schiller’s representation created a situation where they could be accused of bias. Boies Schiller’s counsel urged the court to deny the motion without further briefing, arguing Dershowitz failed to comply with court rules and the motion was “tactical.” The case involves allegations of sexual abuse and human trafficking involving Jeffrey Epstein and multiple underage girls.

An FBI briefing is scheduled for Monday at 3:30 p.m. regarding the Epstein case, involving the ADIC and the FBI New York office. The briefing follows an EM meeting that concludes around 3:30/3:40 p.m. and includes correspondence between FBI personnel and [REDACTED] regarding the case brief.

The email outlines a relatively quiet legal week commencing June 29, 2019, due to the holiday. Key events include: trials for Ahuja and the first day for AUSAs with a swearing-in ceremony and a Matos verdict report. A drone exercise briefing is scheduled with Sarcone. Specific meetings are planned for Tuesday regarding securities mismarking at Premium Point Investments and an Epstein indictment, followed by Ernesto Lopez sentencing for drug-related offenses. Wednesday features pipeline meetings. Thursday is designated as EFTA00021266. Finally, the sender is considering replacements for the trial training program organizers.

An FBI event, designated EFTA00037390, took place on July 1, 2019, from 19:30 to 20:15 at the ADIC Large Conference Room in New York. The event was a brief on the Jeffrey Epstein case, organized by the FBI and marked as X-PERSONAL. A reminder message was sent 15 minutes prior to the start time, scheduled for 3:30 p.m. Attendees included redacted individuals.

The file details a sex trafficking operation conducted between approximately 2002 and 2005, involving the recruitment and exploitation of multiple minor girls (ages 14-17) in New York and Florida.  Epstein lured these girls with promises of money, frequently beginning with massages which escalated into sexual activity. He paid victims hundreds of dollars in cash, with initial recruitment conducted via phone.  A warrant was issued for Epstein’s arrest on multiple charges (18 USC 1591 (a), (b)(2), and (2), and 18 USC 371) and a silent hit notification was put in place.  FBI and NYPD agents were involved, coordinating a response to apprehend Epstein at his New York residence at 9 East 71st Street. The agency is actively monitoring his movements, and a search warrant was executed.  The file outlines a tactical briefing and further preparations for the arrest.  It indicates that Epstein was out of the country at the time, and that a plan for capturing him once he returned was in place.

*   **Timeline:** The operation was scheduled for July 6, 2019, at 4:00 PM, focusing on Epstein’s return to the US via Teterboro Airport. CBP was to detain him upon arrival, followed by coordination with FBI Newark and NYPD for arrest. A subsequent search warrant would be executed at his New York residence. *   **Operational Plan:** The plan involved coordinated efforts between the FBI, NYPD, CBP, and potentially other agencies (SWAT, SCUBA, etc.). The operation’s success relied on Epstein returning to the US as planned. *   **Administrative Details:** Includes contact information for the on-scene commander, prosecutor (SDNY), and emergency reporting procedures. Tactical briefing information and associated equipment lists are also included.

*   **Indictment & Warrant:** Epstein was indicted on federal charges (18 USC 1591, 18 USC 371) in 2019, with an arrest warrant issued. A search warrant for his 9 East 71st Street residence is pending. *   **Arrest Plan:** The planned arrest involves a silent hit notification via CBP upon Epstein's return to the US, with potential apprehension at Teterboro Airport.  If apprehended, NYPD detectives and FBI agents will execute a search warrant at his New York residence. *   **Operational Details:** The operation requires coordination between FBI/NYPD, NYPD, CBP, and ICE. A briefing is scheduled for July 8, 2019, at 11:00 PM in the C-20 squad area.

A legal team is tracking a Florida case involving Jane Doe 1 and 2 and the New York NPA (Non-Prosecution Agreement). They note a recent filing arguing the NPA’s limited scope to Florida crimes and victims. An opposing motion for a sur-reply was filed by Epstein’s lawyer, seeking to discuss the NPA’s scope. The team plans to file an opposition to further briefing extensions and maintains their clients were informed in 2013 that the NPA does not cover New York or other jurisdictions.

An email exchange discusses a briefing in Florida regarding the potential extension of the Florida NPA to New York. A filing by Jane Doe 1 and 2 highlighting the NPA’s limited scope to Florida was sent. A reply brief was filed, followed by a motion for a sur-reply from Epstein’s lawyer arguing for an opportunity to discuss the NPA’s scope. An opposition to the sur-reply motion is planned for Monday. The sender’s client maintains the NPA does not extend to New York or other jurisdictions based on a 2013 communication.

This email chain concerns a briefing regarding a Florida CVRA case involving Jane Doe 1 and 2. The sender, IM, is informing a recipient about recent filings, including a motion for a sur-reply from Epstein's lawyer arguing for an expanded scope of the NPA (National Prosecution Attorney). IM’s clients believe the NPA does not extend to New York or other jurisdictions, and they intend to file an opposition to further briefing extensions. The initial request for a call was prompted by a need to discuss the CVRA and the NPA’s potential application.

On July 26, 2019, an individual (IM) responded to a request for a call regarding a briefing in Florida concerning whether the Florida NPA extends to New York. The sender ([REDACTED]) had previously sent materials related to a CVRA case involving Jane Doe 1 and 2, including a filing and a reply brief. The sender highlighted an argument that the NPA (presumably the National Prosecution Assistance) only covers Florida and that their clients were informed in 2013 that it did not extend to New York. A motion for a sur-reply was filed by Epstein’s lawyer (Marty Weinberg), seeking to discuss the scope of the NPA. The sender stated they would file an opposition to Weinberg’s motion on Monday.

On July 26, 2019, an individual (identified as “Eff”) sent materials to a recipient regarding a Florida CVRA case involving Jane Doe 1 and 2. The attached filing explains an argument that Judge Marra should limit remedies to Florida crimes and victims due to the NPA’s limited scope, which was communicated to clients in 2013 as not extending to New York or other jurisdictions. Subsequently, Marty Weinberg (Epstein’s lawyer) filed a motion for a sur-reply arguing for an opportunity to discuss the NPA’s scope. The sender will file an opposition to this motion on Monday. The sender is admitted to the Utah State Bar but not other state bars.

A series of emails discuss a briefing regarding a Florida CVRA case involving Jane Doe 1 and 2. Key points include: *   A request for a call to discuss the case and the NPA’s scope. *   Updates on filings: a reply brief on remedies was filed, followed by a sur-reply motion from Epstein’s lawyer arguing for continued briefing. *   The sender’s clients were informed in 2013 that the NPA does not extend to New York. *   The sender intends to file an opposition to Weinberg’s motion for a sur-reply. *   The case involves arguments about remedies limited to Florida crimes and Florida victims.

An FBI agent in the New York Field Office’s Criminal – Branch C desk initiated a Special Case Number (SCN) regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation on August 1, 2019. The SCN requires weekly situation reports detailing updates across several investigative areas: victim interviews, digital analysis, financial analysis (including specific bank and brokerage firm investigations), forfeiture, public corruption, and significant events like searches. The agent requested collaboration with SDNY, Squad C-XX, and outside vendor XXXXX. A conference call was scheduled with M, and consideration was given to involving CEOS and CP due to a victim’s statement involving potential child exploitation. The A/SC is briefing the DAD and the agent is coordinating with CEOU for personnel support.

An FBI agent from the New York Field Office’s Criminal – Branch C desk initiated a Special Case Number (SCN) for the Epstein investigation on August 1, 2019. The SCN requires weekly situation reports detailing updates across multiple investigative facets: victim interviews, digital analysis, financial analysis (specifically referencing SDNY, Squad C-XX, and vendor XXXXX), forfeiture, public corruption, and significant events, including the search of Epstein’s island. A conference call was scheduled with M and CEOS to discuss a recent victim’s statement regarding alleged abuse and potential evidence for a CP affidavit. The A/SC is briefing the DAD and the team is exploring bringing in personnel from CEOU.

On August 5, 2019, an email exchange occurred regarding briefing memos for the Attorney General (AG) related to specific investigations. One party requested the final versions of recent update memos for Geoff and the DAG, noting potential involvement in larger memos and missing final drafts. The sender proposed deadlines for these memos to be delivered to Geoff by Thursday or Friday of that week. Attached documents included memos related to SDNY cases and recused documents.

*   A series of emails discuss a legal case (CVRA) involving Epstein and a Florida NPA (Non-Prosecution Agreement). *   An attorney provided a 2008 Florida court transcript where Epstein’s attorney stated the NPA only applied in Florida. *   Discussions centered around whether the NPA extended to New York, with parties arguing the NPA’s scope was limited to Florida. *   Multiple individuals (identified only by redactions) were involved in coordinating information and strategy regarding the case. *   Briefing and motions related to remedies and a sur-reply were exchanged, with plans to file an opposition to extending the briefing.

*   **Update Categories:** The update should include reports on Forfeiture, Public Corruption, Victim Interviews, Hotline Results, Digital Analysis, Financial Analysis, and Other Significant Activity. *   **Specific Tasks:** A specific individual ([REDACTED]) is to initiate a Special Case Number (SCN) and provide weekly sitreps. Financial analysis should focus on accounts at XYZ Bank and ABC Brokerage Firm, specifically referencing payments to XXX. *   **Conference Call:** A conference call is scheduled with M to coordinate the weekly updates, incorporating input from CEOS (likely a specialized unit) and potentially leveraging information from the "taint team TDYs." *   **Key Information:** A victim reported JE's concerning statements regarding sexual assault and the information is considered valuable for an affidavit. The A/SC is briefing the DAD on the case.

A call was made between officers and the warden regarding inmate Epstein’s cellmate policy. The warden indicated the policy was discretionary and that Epstein was expected to have a cellmate at all times. When Epstein’s cellmate was released, he was in the attorney visiting area. Officers are typically briefed on cellmate assignments and have authority to move them. A request was made for written documentation of the cellmate policy and confirmation of the captain’s briefing to the officers.

Steve Smith, a Federal Sales Representative for SigNet Technologies and Convergint Federal Solutions, is scheduling a morning conversation with recipients to discuss the current status of a DVR and plan next steps. He intends to receive a briefing from Jeff and will contact the recipients to coordinate a time. The email includes standard disclaimers regarding confidential information and unauthorized use.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is requesting scans of interview notes related to Jeffrey Epstein’s arrest. They are specifically asking for 302s if available, but notes are preferred initially. The notes are needed to support memos being prepared for supervisory briefings.

An email chain discusses a case (EFTA00027177) and requests assistance with briefing materials. One party suggests providing a timeline and video review notes, while another expresses feeling overwhelmed by the case’s information volume and asks for existing PowerPoint materials. An email request is sent to the U.S. Department of Justice, Office of the Inspector General, New York Field Office for emails related to EFTA00027178.

*   The meeting agenda has been revised to include a briefing with a new ODAG Liaison. *   Attendees are instructed to review their areas of responsibility and provide concise (5-minute or less) presentations. *   The Philadelphia hotel room block has been canceled, and attendees are responsible for canceling their travel arrangements. *   Meeting logistics are detailed, including the Hyatt Regency Washington location, room assignments (A-C training rooms), required identification (PIV card), and business casual attire. *   Weather forecasts and temperature ranges are provided. *   A fee of $25 will be collected for food expenses for the November 2019 meeting. *   PRD support staff will be available for assistance during the meeting.

An email was sent revising the agenda for an Executive Staff meeting scheduled for August 20, 2019, in Washington, DC. The meeting will include “Executive Staff Briefings to ODAG.” The Philadelphia hotel room block has been canceled, and attendees are responsible for canceling their own airfare/train arrangements. The meeting will be held in training rooms A-C on the first floor of the Hyatt Regency Washington on Capital Hill. Attendees are required to bring their government ID and PIV card. The dress attire is business casual, and the weather forecast is for warm, partly cloudy days. $25 will be collected from each attendee for food for the November 2019 meeting. PRD support staff will be available for assistance during the meeting.

On August 28, 2019, an FBI agent (identified as NY/FBI) contacted another FBI agent (NY/FBI) to schedule a call regarding a briefing with VSD and Jeffrey Epstein. The initial contact involved a request to determine availability for an afternoon call the following day.

On September 20, 2019, Bruce Barke proposed a meeting to discuss a proposed schedule, aiming to finalize it by Tuesday.  A subsequent email exchange occurred between Barke and [REDACTED] regarding meeting times, specifically focusing on the following Friday to allow for internal discussion and consultation. The initial proposal included sending a briefing schedule ahead of the meeting.

Bruce Barke proposes a meeting early next week to discuss a proposed schedule. He intends to send a briefing schedule by Tuesday and requests a day and time for the discussion with Tony Ricc and Michael Bachrach. This email includes a confidentiality notice.

Bruce Barket proposes a meeting to discuss a proposed schedule, likely for a briefing, with a target completion date of Tuesday. The meeting is to be held next Friday to allow for internal discussion and consultation with “[REDACTED]”. The email chain includes correspondence between Barket and [REDACTED], with a copy to Tony Ricco and Michael Bachrach.

Bruce Barket, an attorney, is proposing a meeting to discuss a proposed schedule with the Assistant U.S. Attorney. He suggests the 30th or 2nd as potential dates, following up on a previous offer of next Friday afternoon. Barket intends to finalize his proposed briefing schedule by Tuesday.

Bruce Barket (Barket Epstein Kearon Aldea & LoTurco) is coordinating a meeting to propose a schedule for penalty phase pleadings. The Assistant U.S. Attorney and Tonyricco (Learned Counsel) are available next Friday afternoon. Barket intends to finalize a proposed briefing schedule by Tuesday of the following week.  The communication includes contact information for all parties involved and a standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On September 21, 2019, an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York discussed scheduling a meeting with Bruce Barket of Barket Epstein to propose a briefing schedule for the penalty phase of a case (EFTA00021692). The Assistant U.S. Attorney indicated availability next week and mentioned submitting a proposed schedule over the weekend as Learned Counsel, in compliance with ABA Guidelines. Bruce Barket suggested times of 12:00-1:00 or 4:00, and the Assistant U.S. Attorney confirmed those times worked, pending confirmation from the rest of the defense team.

An email chain discusses scheduling a meeting to propose a briefing schedule for a penalty phase. Several individuals—including Assistant U.S. Attorneys, Bruce Barket, and Tonyricco—suggest Thursday afternoon as a possible time, contingent on receiving a proposal from BB by Tuesday. Tonyricco also states he will submit a proposed schedule over the weekend as Learned Counsel, compliant with ABA Guidelines.

Bruce Barket (Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco) is working on a proposed schedule for penalty phase pleadings. He was corresponding with Tonyricco (Assistant U.S. Attorney) and another individual regarding availability for a meeting to discuss the schedule. Barket intended to finalize and send a proposed briefing schedule by Tuesday, September 24th, and requested a meeting sometime next week.
An email was sent from [REDACTED] with the subject "Accepted: Epstein Victim Briefings" on September 26, 2019. The email is attached to document EFTA00038185.

On October 2, 2019, at 17:00:00 GMT, a personal briefing titled "Epstein Victim Briefings" took place in the 290 9th Floor Conference Room. The event was created on September 26, 2019, and included a reminder to correct a time discrepancy (1:00 PM instead of 1:30 PM). The event was classified as “X-PERSONAL” and had a priority of 5.

On October 2, 2019, at 1:00 PM, a meeting titled “Epstein Victim Briefings” took place in the 9th Floor Conference Room. The meeting was classified as “X-PERSONAL,” created on September 26, 2019, and had a priority of 5. A reminder was issued regarding the time of the meeting.

An FBI event, designated EFTA00037734, took place on October 2, 2019, from 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM at the FBI’s 9th Floor Conference Room. The event was classified as X-PERSONAL and focused on “Epstein Victim Briefings.” A reminder was issued to attendees regarding the start time.

An event titled “Epstein Victim Briefings” took place on 2019-10-02 from 17:30:00 to 18:30:00 +0000 at 290 9th Floor Conference Room. The event was classified as ‘X-PERSONAL’, created on 2019-09-26, and had a priority of 5. A reminder was set to display a message 15 minutes before the start. The document is identified as EFTA00037733.

An event titled “Epstein Victim Briefings” took place on 2019-10-02 from 17:30:00 to 18:30:00 at 290 9th Floor Conference Room. It was created on 2019-09-26 and categorized as “X-PERSONAL” with a priority of 5. A reminder was scheduled to display a message 1 hour before the start.

On October 2, 2019, from 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM, a meeting titled "Epstein Victim Briefings" took place in the 9th Floor Conference Room (290 9th Floor Conference Room). The event was classified as “X-PERSONAL,” created on September 26, 2019, and assigned a priority of 5.

On October 2, 2019, at 5:00 PM GMT, a personal briefing occurred titled “Epstein Victim Briefings” in the 9th Floor Conference Room. The event was created on September 26, 2019, and included a reminder to adjust the time to 1:00 PM GMT. The event was designated as priority 5.

An email exchange occurred between [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] on October 7, 2019, regarding contact information. One party (likely a counsel to the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York) sent an email attachment containing case briefing overviews and anticipated briefers. A reply confirmed receipt and appreciation for the assistance, referencing the U.S. Attorney’s Office address: One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007, and including the identifier EFTA00029991.

On October 7, 2019, Alex Conlon from KaplanHecker & Fink LLP received an email from the FBI Victim Services Division regarding briefings for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI was offering two briefings: October 15th in Miami and October 23rd in New York.  The email requested information from law firms representing victims, including full names, firm names, contact information, security details (SSN, address, citizenship, country of birth), and details about the victim(s) and the specific briefing being attended.  A follow-up email on September 27, 2019, reiterated the invitation and requested additional clients not initially contacted. The emails contained disclaimers regarding confidential and protected information.

A briefing regarding the Epstein case, identified as EFTA00038227, was conducted on October 8, 2019. The analysis of digital evidence is pending due to ongoing taint team review. Ghislaine Maxwell and an attorney had a proffer on October 8, 2019, and another attorney proffer on October 7, 2019. Approximately 80 victims have been identified, with hundreds more unidentified. Two briefings were scheduled in Miami and NYC on October 11, 2019.

Jillian Gonzales, an associate producer for The Dr. Oz Show, contacted VictimServices at the FBI on October 14, 2019, inquiring about the objective and accessibility of an FBI briefing for Jeffrey Epstein survivors held in NYC on October 23, 2019. The email chain was forwarded to the FBI for response.

On October 15, 2019, Jillian Gonzales, an associate producer for The Dr. Oz Show, emailed the FBI New York’s Victims Services Unit inquiring about the objective and accessibility of an FBI briefing for survivors of Jeffrey Epstein held in NYC on October 23rd. A Public Affairs Specialist responded, stating the FBI would not be able to assist due to the nature of the inquiry. Jillian Gonzales then emailed the FBI New York again on October 14, 2019, reiterating her request for information about the briefing.

The FBI Victim Services Division is offering an RSVP for a briefing regarding the Epstein case. The briefing is scheduled for October 15, 2019 in Miami, FL and October 23, 2019 in New York, NY. Attendees are required to complete a form collecting personal information, including contact details, citizenship, and travel preferences (transportation mode, dates, and airports). Attendees can bring one support person who also requires a separate form to be completed, including their personal details and travel preferences.  Lodging and mileage reimbursement are authorized, with specific restrictions on incidental charges and authorized expenses.  Attendees must acknowledge understanding of the limitations of authorized expenses, specifically excluding meals, rental vehicles, and entertainment.

An email chain discusses arrangements for a meeting involving three legal firms and FBI Victim Services Division regarding a briefing for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The meeting is scheduled for October 23, 2019, at 10:00 AM. Attendees are advised to bring identification, avoid electronic devices, and arrive by 9:30 AM. Parking and transportation information are provided, and updates/questions should be submitted to a designated email inbox. The meeting's purpose is to be respectful and cooperative.

The FBI Victim Services Division is offering a briefing to victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The briefing will be held on October 15th in Miramar, Florida, or October 23rd in New York, NY. Attendees are asked to complete and return an RSVP Questionnaire to VictimServices@fbi.gov, providing personal information for security purposes. Transportation and lodging will be provided free of charge for those residing more than 50 miles from the location, with mileage reimbursement available for self-drivers. The meeting will involve FBI representatives, the FBI NY Field Office, and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

An email chain discusses scheduling meetings with individuals regarding interviews with Jeffrey Epstein victims. Four additional victims are identified and slated to attend a briefing in New York on October 23rd. The sender, E. Edwards of Pottinger LLC, offers to provide information about the victims and schedules meetings for October 23rd or 24th.  Attachments include an image labeled "image001.png" and another document labeled EFTA00037938.

An email exchange discusses whether to request attendee information (specifically attorneys) to gain access to a building for a briefing. The exchange questions whether transportation, hotel, or reimbursements should be provided to the attorneys. An RSVP questionnaire was attached.

An email exchange discusses scheduling meetings with four individuals representing victims who wish to speak about their experiences with Jeffrey Epstein. One party (MINIME) expresses willingness to meet with the victims and suggests discussing their background beforehand. The other party (Illia/Pottenger LLC) proposes meetings on October 23rd or 24th following a victim briefing in New York. Contact information for EFTA00037940 is also included.

Diane Aldrich of Allred Maroko Goldberg sent questionnaires to the FBI Victim Services regarding co-counsel for Gloria Allred and related Epstein clients. The questionnaires were for attendees of an FBI Victim Services briefing scheduled for October 23rd in New York. The attachments were DM_Signed_Form.pdf and MW_Signed_Form.pdf.

An email chain discusses an FBI briefing on October 23rd for survivors of Jeffrey Epstein, held in NYC. The briefing was initiated by the FBI Victim Services Division and prompted an inquiry from Jillian Gonzales of The Dr. Oz Show regarding the briefing’s objective and accessibility.  The email includes correspondence between FBI personnel and a forwarded message from the FBI Victim Services Division to Dr. Oz’s production team. EFTA00037407 and EFTA00037408 are identified as file identifiers.

Indyke) involving claims against Jeffrey Epstein’s estate. Judge Katherine Polk Failla presided over the meeting, attended by attorneys from Kaplan Hecker & Fink (representing the plaintiffs) and Troutman Sanders LLP (representing the estate’s executors). The primary focus of the conference was a motion filed by the plaintiffs to dismiss punitive damages claims against the estate. The estate’s attorneys, Bennet Moskowitz and Charles Glover, proposed establishing a fund to settle claims, arguing that the plaintiffs were not fully engaged with this process. There was a disagreement over the scope of discovery, with the plaintiffs advocating for a more thorough investigation and the estate arguing for a more limited approach. Key points of contention included: the lack of a defined amount for the settlement fund, the plaintiffs’ skepticism towards the settlement process, and the applicability of New York law versus Virgin Islands law regarding punitive damages. The plaintiffs argued for dismissing punitive damages based on New York statute, while the estate maintained that its lawyers were exploring different jurisdictions for potential claims.  Ultimately, the judge did not immediately schedule a briefing on the motion but requested further communication and a discussion about the claims administration process.

An email exchange occurred between the Victim Program Management Unit and two individuals regarding whether they were victims in a case involving Jeffrey Epstein. One individual confirmed they were victims, citing invoices from a service provider and the fact that they did not attend briefings. The other individual did not respond.

Thomas Brown of Berkeley Research Group, LLC proposes a computer forensics engagement for approximately 57 devices (hard drives, mobile devices, and portable media). The scope includes data extraction, parsing, Relativity file creation, data analysis, and team briefings. The engagement would be staffed by two junior staff members supervised by a senior staff member (a former FBI computer scientist) and managed by a director. The estimated timeline is 30 days. The budget ranges from $85,000 to $135,000, covering hourly rates for staff and the director, plus fees for blank hard drives, thumb drives, and device image recovery.

Email correspondence regarding revised “shortened talking points.” The email chain outlines a request for a briefing book update (AS_AG_BriefingBookjas_of 6.24.20) with specific instructions to keep talking points concise, particularly for meetings with the Attorney General (AG), due to time constraints. A revised version of the talking points was provided, with one exception (GEP) remaining at a shorter length.

A briefing book, titled “AS AG Briefing_Book Jas_of 6.24.20 (final).pdf,” was prepared for a meeting. The document includes charging statistics comparing last year and this year to illustrate the impact of COVID-19 on productivity. An additional attachment, “COVID_Filings_Comparison.pdf,” is also included.

On June 24, 2020, an email exchange occurred between multiple redacted individuals regarding a briefing book. The sender, [REDACTED], requested a version of the briefing book that could be edited, specifically asking about the format of the documents – either individual word documents or one combined word document. Seven talking point documents were attached: “alMIN>”, “I_GEP_1-_Global_Energy_Producers_-_Talking_Pointsv2.docx”, “2_-_Maxwell_1-Jeffrey_Epstein_Co-Conspirators_Talking_Points,.v2.docx”, “3-_W_1_-_Wall_Talking_Points.v2.docx”, “4_-_TPC_In_The_Presidential_Coalition_-Talking_Pointsv2.docx”, “5_-_NRA_1_-_Talking_Points.docx”, and “6_-_AOC_1_-Investigation Talking_Points.docx”.

A document discusses the redaction of victim names from a deposition related to litigation involving Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The Circuit has ordered briefing by August 20th to discuss the deposition with Boies. A previous email indicates awareness of Maxwell’s deposition being unsealed by Judge Preska, raising concerns about victim confidentiality.

Ghislaine Maxwell* case (20 Cr. 330). Specifically, she seeks to allow her to refer to and file under seal in the *Giuffre v. Maxwell* (15-cv-5433) and Second Circuit appeal (No. 20-2413) certain discovery materials produced by the government, primarily from August 5, 2020, and a large batch from Boies Schiller & Flexner. The request stems from a need for fair determination of key issues impacting her privacy and due process rights. Maxwell argues that the government has essentially turned over all discovery materials produced in both the *Giuffre* and Jane Doe 43 cases. She believes this has been done secretly, in conjunction with Boies Schiller, and that this information was not fully disclosed to her. Maxwell asserts that the government's actions violate the Protective Order, which exempts information obtained “from a source other than the government,” and that she’s acting out of “abundance of caution.” She highlights a conflict between the government’s actions and a court order that the government must comply with when producing documents. The motion further argues that the unsealing of these materials is justified because the documents are “judicial documents” with a presumptive right of public access and that the government’s interference with the process is unfair. The motion also points to an emergency stay of unsealing ordered by the Second Circuit pending briefing. Finally, the document contends the court should allow her to use the materials under seal for her defense in the ongoing legal proceedings.

15 Civ. 7433) against her. New, critical information has emerged impacting both this case and a related criminal action (20 Cr. 330) involving U.S. v. Maxwell. This information relates to Maxwell’s due process rights and Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendment protections. Counsel seeks a temporary three-week stay of the unsealing process to allow for consultation with the U.S. Attorney's Office and a potential modification of the protective order. They propose streamlining the unsealing process through modifications to the protocol, including reduced briefing page limits and a shorter objection response period. Counsel also requests the court allow for a 7-day period for Non-Parties to object after a sealing order. Finally, they propose prioritizing specific decided motions for unsealing, excluding those tied to the paused deposition transcripts.

An FBI email, dated October 16, 2020, was sent from the FBI to the NY FBI and MilliS, regarding a briefing call about Jeffrey Epstein. The email included dial-in information for the call (303-586-4335 or 1-877-446-3914) and a passcode. A Special Agent (SA) was also scheduled to join the call.

An FBI briefing call, designated EFTA00038046, took place on October 16, 2020, from 16:00:00 to 17:00:00 GMT. The organizer was the FBI, and attendees included representatives from ODAG, JMD, and NY (FBI). The call was marked as X-PERSONAL and had a priority of 5. A reminder message was to be displayed 15 minutes before the start, and the dial-in numbers were 303-586-4335 and 1-877-446-3914 with a guest passcode. The call was related to a conversation with SA.

This email provides dial-in information for a call regarding the Epstein Briefing. The call is between the FBI (DO and NY) and ODAG (JMD) and CRT. The email was sent on October 20, 2020, with the subject "Epstein Briefing Check-In."

An event, titled “Epstein Briefing Conference Call,” took place on 2020-10-23 from 18:30:00 to 19:30:00 GMT. The organizer created a personal, high-priority event. The call’s purpose was to discuss invitation/RSVP status, DOJ packet content requests, and refreshment/funding details. A reminder message was set to display 15 minutes prior to the call’s start.

An email chain discusses an ODAG/FBI briefing conference call scheduled for November 2, 2020, at 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time. Attachments include a Survivor Master list with highlighted victim contact information and an RSVP tracking spreadsheet. The FBI is following up on Sigrid’s victim list and a Dubai request.  The call involves participants from ODAG, FBI, CRT, and NY (FBI).

An email chain discusses an ODAG/FBI briefing conference call scheduled for November 2, 2020, at 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM UTC-05:00 Eastern Time. The call details include the conference line number EFTA00038161 and a guest passcode EFTA00038162. Attachments include a master list of attendees and an RSVP tracking spreadsheet. The email originates from multiple FBI and ODAG entities.

An email chain discusses draft talking points for a victim briefing regarding child exploitation and human trafficking. The Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG), specifically the Acting Chief Privacy and Civil Liberties Officer (OPCL), requests input and comments on the talking points, including topics to avoid or expand upon, with a deadline of November 10, 2020. The email involves multiple recipients within the U.S. Department of Justice including OPR, OPR, OPCL, OLA, USAGAN, and USANYS.

This is an FBI document, Case ID # EFTA00025005, concerning the case of Jeffrey Epstein and a child sex trafficking investigation. It details outreach support efforts following an OPR briefing on findings dated November 11, 2020. An updated contact information list as of November 18, 2020 is included as an enclosure.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a briefing and Judge Nathan’s order to [REDACTED] regarding a litigation concerning the disclosure of victim names identified in an indictment by number. The litigation stemmed from a previous discussion with VOC chiefs about a prior case before Judge Nathan. Attached documents included a briefing and the Judge’s order denying a defense motion for victim identities.

A debriefing titled “ODAG Epstein Debrief” was canceled on November 16, 2020, from 20:30:00 to 21:30:00 GMT. The event was organized under the classification “X-PERSONAL” and created on November 16, 2020, at 18:22:01 GMT.  It was assigned a priority of 1 and attendee invitations were sent.

A debriefing titled “ODAG Epstein Debrief” was scheduled for November 16, 2020, from 20:30 to 21:30. The event was canceled and was designated as X-PERSONAL. The meeting was created on November 16, 2020, and last modified on November 17, 2020. It had a priority of 1.

An ODAG Epstein debriefing event took place on November 16, 2020, from 20:30:00 to 21:30:00 GMT. The event was organized, attended, and created by individuals identified as EFTA00038150. It had a priority of 5 and included a reminder with the message "CALL" and a guest passcode of EFTA00038150. A display alarm was scheduled to activate 5 minutes before the start.

Emails discuss scheduling a briefing regarding the Epstein case on November 5th or 12th, potentially at the Miami FO All-Employee Conference Room. A draft invitation/RSVP with preliminary comments was prepared and circulated. The briefing includes details on the purpose, date, location, support person language, COVID precautions (temperature checks, CDC screening, social distancing, mandatory masks), RSVP deadline, and a request for advance questions from victims. Attachments include a questionnaire, letter template, name tag key, and COVID procedures. The sender is awaiting clearance from DOJ components and confirmation of the confirmed date to begin outreach to Victim Specialists.

Emails discuss scheduling a briefing related to the Epstein case, specifically on November 5th and 12th. The draft invitation includes details such as the briefing purpose, date, location (Time TBD), support person language, COVID precautions (temperature checks, screenings, social distancing, masks), RSVP deadline, and a request for victim questions. Documents attached include a draft invitation, RSVP questionnaire, a template letter, a name tag key, and Miami COVID procedures. The sender is seeking confirmation of a confirmed date to identify Victim Specialists for assistance in Miami.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is being informed that Ghislaine Maxwell’s attorneys intend to file a new bail application. The application has not yet been filed, and there is no set briefing schedule or hearing date. The sender requests to be kept updated and offers to discuss the matter.

Ghislaine Maxwell’s legal team requested to redact portions of a letter submitted to the court seeking release on bail. The court, with government consent, approved the proposed redactions, citing the Lugosch test which balances judicial access with privacy concerns. The court determined the letter was a “judicial document” and that the defendant’s privacy interests outweighed the presumption of access. The defendant was ordered to file the redacted letters by December 4, 2020, and the parties were instructed to prepare a briefing schedule for a renewed motion for release on bail.

On December 4, 2020, Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a draft letter to Judge Nathan regarding a briefing schedule. The letter was attached as a .DOCX file. He requested confirmation from the recipient ([REDACTED]) that there were no comments before sending the letter within the hour. The email also included images and a confidentiality notice.

An email exchange occurred between individuals at [REDACTED] regarding the Epstein case. One party instructed another to hold off on any contact with the assigned team until the following week to allow for briefing. Contact information was provided.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is requesting a specific document – a file folder titled “File folder entitled se (N.Y. AUSA)” containing handwritten notes – from an individual (“”) who has been tracking related files. The document was identified by box numbers tfl P-003679 through P-003680 and is linked to a privilege log concerning a CVRA lawsuit involving Jeffrey Epstein. The request was initiated on February 17, 2021, and the recipient is seeking assistance with a current briefing related to the file.

On February 18, 2021, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested a specific document (“item on page 5 of the log”) identified by box numbers P-003679 through P-003680, related to the Jeffrey Epstein file. The request was made due to a briefing on a CVRA lawsuit issue. A colleague, [REDACTED], was tasked with retrieving the document, but was experiencing difficulties due to issues with vendor-provided scans. Another colleague, [REDACTED], was contacted to confirm if the document was already available from previous scans. A 25% work schedule was in effect in the office.

An email chain discusses a briefing regarding the suppression of victim identification in the Epstein/Maxwell extradition case. A request was made for a document outlining previously highlighted information related to this suppression, specifically in response to a Canadian Justice Department’s request for a “publication ban” to prevent defense counsel from identifying victims. An attached document, a letter from GMJetter to Judge Nathan, is referenced.

A letter was sent from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to counsel regarding a superseding indictment in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (S2 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The letter discusses discovery issues and the potential for supplemental briefing on pretrial motions due to the new charges, offering availability for discussion between 1pm-5:30pm the following day.

The document is a legal filing arguing for a continuance in the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell* due to a late-filed superseding indictment. The indictment adds significant charges and expands the conspiracy timeline, disrupting trial preparations and potentially infringing on Ms. Maxwell’s constitutional rights, including the right to effective assistance of counsel. The defense argues the government’s actions were tactical, prompted by defense motions, and have fundamentally altered the case’s trajectory, jeopardizing a timely trial. They request a new briefing schedule and consider a motion for a continuance, potentially seeking home detention, and insist on an in-person arraignment with specific requests for witnesses and an evidence review session.

This document is a bail briefing regarding Maxwell, attached to emails from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The attachments include a bail appeal motion, an opinion order, a bail denial order, and a conference report related to an initial hearing.

An email exchange concerning a moot related to the Epstein FOIA is documented. The email chain originates from an Assistant United States Attorney at 300 Quarropas Street, White Plains, NY 10601. It includes attachments of a Times’ reply brief and briefing/declaration documents. Participants include individuals from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and the email addresses of those involved are redacted. The email discusses an "all-star cast," oversubscription, a dial-in invite, and the participation of BOP personnel.

An FBI Special Agent from the New York Field Office is following up on a request for physical evidence related to Case 72. The agent received an email from another agent requesting an update on the evidence’s status and was informed that the agent was occupied with other tasks and upcoming travel. The initial email thread discusses the status of reviewing Maxwell letters and briefings.

An email exchange occurred between [REDACTED] and Strauss, Audrey (USANYS) regarding a FOIA response related to documents pertaining to Jeffrey Epstein. [REDACTED] stated they would provide a briefing and sent it to Strauss, who requested materials to review over the weekend. The email mentions a “Main Justice” perspective on the FOIA response and a potential for further documents to be produced through reconsideration, referencing document EFTA00015360.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted an individual regarding the case *United States v. Nader* (19 Cr. 201 (LMB)). The AUSA had read the individual’s brief and requested a call to discuss a retroactivity issue related to the case. The individual responded with a positive opinion regarding the case, attaching it for the AUSA’s review. Another individual sent a brief email offering contact information and expressing gratitude for the helpful briefing.

Judge Nathan granted additional time for supplemental briefing in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (Case 20cr330). The order, attached as 20cr330_Order 11.10.21.pdf, will be docketed the following morning.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is submitting redacted versions of three documents to the court: a briefing on birth certificates, a remaining briefing on GX-52, and the Government’s motion to quash. The U.S. Attorney proposes a filing process involving a cover letter, redacted document submissions, and responses from the defense. The defense is not proposing any redactions to the submitted documents.

A communication discusses a briefing regarding the admissibility of mental health evidence in the Sasso case. An attachment, including a motion to preclude evidence and a judge’s opinion, was sent from the United States Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York, to another party (USANYS). The process of redacting and sealing information related to the case is described as complicated and requires coordination with S. Nine experts have been deposed in the litigation.

Emails discuss a response to defense counsel’s attempt to call numerous agents involved in an investigation to impeach it. A MIL briefing and transcript of a Judge Nathan ruling (pages 15-30) are attached, aiming to preclude the defense from attacking the investigation. One party has already been addressing the issue in Maxwell and sent a briefing regarding this.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York communicated with Bobbi C. Sternheim regarding articles flagged for potential reporting issues. David Boies and Sigrid McCawley, counsel for the case, confirmed that they and their client have no intention of providing press briefings during the upcoming trial and have complied with SDNY Local Rule 23.1. Sternheim provided her updated contact information in a separate email attachment.

On January 14, 2022, Judge Alison J. Nathan scheduled Ghislaine Maxwell’s sentencing for June 28, 2022, at 11:00 a.m. The Court delayed preparing a presentence investigation report until April 2022 and maintained the existing schedule for briefing on the new trial motion and other post-verdict motions. The Government was instructed to indicate by January 18, 2022, whether it seeks an exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act for the perjury counts, along with the basis for that request.

The Federal Bureau of Prisons (FBOP) is responding to the Office of the Inspector General’s (OIG) final report regarding Jeffrey Epstein’s custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.  The FBOP has completed its review and offers updates on six recommendations made by the OIG: 1.  **Cellmate Assignment:** The FBOP states guidance on assigning cellmates following suicide watch is drafted and under review, with exemptions based on individual or security considerations. 2.  **Continued Cellmates for High-Risk Inmates:**  Similar guidance is being drafted to ensure continued cellmates for inmates at high risk, with exemptions. 3.  **Social/Legal Visit Approvals:**  Guidance on obtaining and documenting approvals for social and legal visits is being drafted, aiming to mitigate security issues. 4.  **Inmate Wellbeing Accounting:**  The FBOP is modifying Program Statement 5500.14 to improve accounting for inmate whereabouts and wellbeing. 5.  **Lieutenant Round Training:**  Program Statement 5500.14 is being modified to clarify Lieutenant training requirements including cell searches, emergency mock discussions, and daily briefings. 6.  **Staffing Shortages:** The FBOP is analyzing incentives and will implement the Automated Staffing Tool, along with utilizing direct-hire authority and a nationwide salary rate request. Additionally, the FBOP highlights ongoing efforts to address cell search procedures, documenting camera system functionality, and implementing a new Security Camera Monthly Report effective June 1, 2024. The FBOP requests closure of Recommendation 7 after completing its evaluations and providing documentation, and indicates it is actively working on finalizing policy updates for Recommendations 8 and other areas.

Robert Glassman of Panish Shea & Boyle was informed by an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York that Ghislaine Maxwell’s attorneys intend to file a new bail application. The application hadn’t been filed yet, and there was no set briefing schedule or hearing date. The Assistant U.S. Attorney stated they would provide updates.

This document is an instructor guide for “Back 2 Basics,” a training module focused on managing housing units within a correctional facility. The module, titled “Managing Housing Units, Part II,” covers five activities designed to train personnel in conducting various checks and audits. These activities include an area search, cell search, irregular round, bed book audit, and a daily fire and security check. Each activity specifies objectives, instructor-to-participant ratios, prerequisites, materials needed, and detailed instructions for execution and debriefing. A key emphasis is on accountability of materials and adherence to facility-specific procedures, requiring completion of “Managing Housing Units, Part I” before proceeding.

An Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is informing recipients of Ghislaine Maxwell’s attorneys’ intention to file a new bail application. The application has not yet been filed, and a briefing schedule or hearing date is undetermined. The sender intends to provide updates and encourages recipients to contact them with questions.
